info.document:
CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

RANDOM LAKE -- High school years are said to be some of the best years of a person's life.

For better or worse, moments occurring doing those four years are remembered decades after the fact.

That's definitely true for former Random Lake star football player Luke Hagel.

Hagel is second in state history in career rushing yards with 6,495 and has the most 200-yard games (16) and 100-yard games (32) of any back.

He's also the all-time scoring leader for a career (802 points) and season (317) while tying for must rushing touchdowns (98).

Glory Days: Plymouth alum Mueller found football family at UW-Whitewater

Glory Days:Sheboygan South grad Will Hartmann proud of Wisconsin journey from walk-on to scholarship

The former standout even was named the Wendy's High School Heisman as a senior and got to visit New York City and see former Texas Longhorn Ricky Williams win the collegiate Heisman.

Yet, the memory which burns brightest in his mind is how the Rams came up just short of a state title his senior year in 1998.

Random Lake fell to Colby in the Division 4 championship game 21-14 and Hagel can vividly recall what happened after nearly two decades.

The game was tied 14-14 midway through the fourth quarter when the Hornets executed a fake punt play called post and reached the endzone to break the tie.

It wasn't over, but the two subsequent offensive series for the Rams stalled out and just like that Random Lake's only state championship appearance ended in defeat.

"I still get worked up about that game to this day," Hagel said reciting the game's turning point.

What followed for Hagel was a career at Ripon which saw the Random Lake alum get inducted into the school's athletic hall of fame.

Hagel initially chose Ripon because they were open to having him play both football and baseball, but following his freshman year a change was needed.

"I had more success in football but when I got to college I knew baseball was where my heart lied," Hagel said.

The break from football lasted only two years. When he asked to rejoin the team as a senior, he was welcomed back with open arms.

"I missed football enough I had to get one more year," Hagel said.

Hagel relishes the fact he got the opportunity to play both sports while at Ripon, even if football was just for two years.

"It's great to do that at the collegiate level for a strong athletic program like Ripon," Hagel said.

Looking back, Hagel knows the choice to temporarily give up football was a tough decision but was ultimately the correct one.

"Over the years it would have been nice to have a full career at Ripon for both sports but it was the right choice," Hagel said.

While it might be tempting to say a collegiate hall of fame career is what was most memorable, Hagel's time on the Ripon baseball team gave him something even more special -- friendships.

"A lot of guys who were on the team with me are my best friends," Hagel said. "We've stood up in each others weddings, still play poker and fantasy baseball together."

Despite his competitive nature, those connections are what Hagel cherishes most when reflecting on his athletic career.

"All my best friends come from relationships on the sports field one way or another," Hagel said. "Sports is where it began."
